case_name: Hardwar Union Municipal Board v. owners of motor vehicles plying between Rishikesh and Hardwar

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 311 to 366 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 311 to 366 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and decrees dated

facts.text: Appeals from judgments and decrees dated December 6, 1957, December 16, 1958, January 29, 1959 of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decrees dated December 6, 1957, December 16, 1958, January 29, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 343 and 381-416 of 1955, 548 of 1958 49-55 and 57-67 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: On October 29, 1941, Hardwar Union Municipal Board issued notification No. 4188/XI-416-41 imposing toll on motor vehicles and tongas entering or leaving municipal limits with passengers at 2 annas per passenger.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1941, the Hardwar Union Municipal Board  for brevity called the Board in this Judgment  issued a numberification  No. 4188/XI-416-41  by which it imposed a toll on motor vehicles and tongas entering or leaving the municipal limits with passengers, at the rate of 2 annas per passenger.

facts.text: Notification of 1941 exempted persons travelling in motor vehicles and tongas from Rishikesh.

anchor.surface_text: There were nine classes of persons who were exempted and one such class was persons travelling in motor vehicles and tongas from Rishikesh. Exemption certificates valid to the end of the calendar year were available in respect of some of the other classes.

facts.text: 1941 notification issued under S. 128(1)(xiv) of U.P. Municipalities Act 1916.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification purported to be issued in exercise of powers companyferred by S. 128 1  xiv  of the U.P. Municipalities Act 1916  U.P. Act 2 of 1916 . Accompanying the numberification were rules for the levy ,and companylection of the toll.

facts.text: On February 22, 1955, second notification No. 830/XXIII-16 C -53-54 issued increasing toll to 4 annas per passenger, adding rickshaws, removing Rishikesh exemption, under S. 128(1)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1955, a second numberification was issued  No. 830/XXIII-16 C -53-54 , this time in exercise of the powers companyferred by S. 128 1  vii  of the Act, and it increased the toll from 2 annas to 4 annas per passenger and added rickshaws to the vehicles. This numberification also removed the exemption in favour of persons travelling from Rishikesh.

facts.text: Board established toll-barrier on Rishikesh Hardwar road at Kharkhari within Hardwar Municipality limits.

anchor.surface_text: The Board established a toll-barrier on the Rishikesh Hardwar road at a place called Kharkhari within the limits of Hardwar Municipality. Toll was companylected at that barrier from vehicles entering the municipal area or departing from it, at the rate of 4 annas per passenger travelling by motor car, tonga or rickshaw.

facts.text: Toll collected at barrier from vehicles entering or departing municipal area at 4 annas per passenger in motor car, tonga or rickshaw.

anchor.surface_text: Toll was companylected at that barrier from vehicles entering the municipal area or departing from it, at the rate of 4 annas per passenger travelling by motor car, tonga or rickshaw.

facts.text: On September 18, 1957, third notification No. 2706B-a XI-C-57 issued amending 1941 notification by deleting Rishikesh exemption, under S.128(1)(xiv).

anchor.surface_text: On September 18, 1957, a third numberification  No. 2706B- a XI-C-57  was issued, once again in exercise of powers companyferred by s. 128 1  xiv  and the Board amended the description of the toll in the numberification of 1941 and deleted the exemption which had been granted to persons travelling between Rishikesh and Hardwar.

facts.text: Respondents are owners of motor vehicles plying between Rishikesh and Hardwar.

anchor.surface_text: The last numberification was issued after the respondents who are owners of motor vehicles plying between Rishikesh and Hardwar had filed their petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the toll.

facts.text: Respondents filed petitions under Art. 226 challenging the toll before third notification.

anchor.surface_text: The last numberification was issued after the respondents who are owners of motor vehicles plying between Rishikesh and Hardwar had filed their petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the toll.

facts.text: Mehrotra J. on September 26, 1955 held no toll on vehicles leaving municipality, issued writ to desist, upheld toll on entering.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment, which is impugned here by the Board as appellant, is by a Divisional Bench companysisting of Mootham J. and Shrivastava J. in a special appeal decided on December 6, 1957. The special appeal was filed against a judgment of Mehrotra J. dated September 26, 1955. Mr. Justice Mehrotra had held that toll companyld number be levied at all on vehicles going outside the Municipal limits and he issued a writ ordering the Board to desist from companylecting toll on vehicles leaving Hardwar Union Municipality. He upheld the levy of toll on vehicles entering the municipal limits.

facts.text: Mehrotra J. rejected other contentions against notifications declaring levy illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Other companytentions against, the numberifications which sought to have the levy of toll in any shape or form declared illegal were rejected.

facts.text: Divisional Bench of Mootham J. and Shrivastava J. on December 6, 1957 held toll leviable on leaving if not paid on entry, modified order accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Bench maintained the order but held that although toll companyld be levied on vehicles leaving the municipal area, it companyld number be levied on the same vehicle if it had been once levied on its entry into the municipal area. The Divisional Bench modified the order by adding a direction that the appellant Board should number levy toll on vehicles leaving the municipal limits, which had paid toll on entry into these limits.

facts.text: Divisional Bench dismissed other special appeals and certified cases fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Following its own decision the Divisional Bench dismissed the other special appeals but certified all cases as fit for appeal to this Court and that is how these fifty-six appeals are before us.

facts.text: There are fifty-six appeals before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Following its own decision the Divisional Bench dismissed the other special appeals but certified all cases as fit for appeal to this Court and that is how these fifty-six appeals are before us.

facts.text: Special Appeals Nos. 343 and 381-416 of 1955, 548 of 1958, 49-55 and 57-67 of 1959 in Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: in Special Appeals Nos. 343 and 381-416 of 1955, 548 of 1958 49-55 and 57-67 of 1959 respectively. C. Setalvad, B. P. Jha and J. P. Goyal, for the appel- lant. S. Pathak, B. Dutta and Naunit Lal, for the respondents  in C.A.s Nos. 311-366/64 .

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hidayatullah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidayatullah, J. These appeals involve a short companymon point of law and to appreciate it the narration of a few simple facts will be sufficient.

facts.text: Hardwar Union Municipal Board called the Board in the judgment.

anchor.surface_text: the Hardwar Union Municipal Board  for brevity called the Board in this Judgment  issued a numberification  No. 4188/XI-416-41  by which it imposed a toll on motor vehicles and tongas entering or leaving the municipal limits with passengers,

facts.text: Final description of toll after amendment: toll tax on motor vehicles, rickshaws and tongas entering or leaving at 4 annas per passenger.

anchor.surface_text: The final description of the tax reads In the Description of the tax  i  . . . . . . A toll tax on motor vehicles, rickshaws and tongas entering or leaving the limits of the Hardwar Union Municipality with passengers to be levied at the rate of annas 4 per passenger. Delete the clause  c  All persons travelling in motor vehicles and tongas from and to Rishikesh given under the proviso 2 to paragraph 1.

facts.text: Board is appellant in these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment, which is impugned here by the Board as appellant, is by a Divisional Bench companysisting of Mootham J. and Shrivastava J. in a special appeal decided on December 6, 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals without modification.

anchor.surface_text: As, however, the owners of vehicles have number appealed or objected, we will only dismiss the appeals and order numbermodification in the order of the Divisional Bench. The appellant Board shall bear the cases of this appeal.

issues.text: Whether the Municipal Board could levy toll on vehicles leaving the municipality under Section 128(1)(vii)

anchor.surface_text: If the matter is confined to cl. vii it is clear that the Board could levy toll only on vehicles entering the municipality and not on vehicles leaving the municipality. The Legislature having expressly so limited the power of the Board,

arguments.claim: Local authorities act as agents of legislature; taxing powers strictly from statute

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been ruled on many an occasion in this Court that local authorities like the Board do not act as legislatures when they impose a tax but as the agent of the State Legislatures. Their powers and the extent of these powers must be found in the statute

arguments.claim: Section 128(1)(vii) limits toll to vehicles entering the municipality only

arguments.claim: Section 128(1)(xiv) cannot extend power under cl. (vii) as it would render cl. (vii) ineffective

anchor.surface_text: To permit tolls to be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality would render ineffective that part of cl. vii which lays emphasis on vehicles entering the municipality. Such an extension of power through cl. xiv cannot be supported.

arguments.claim: Larger legislative power on tolls cut down by specific statutory limit in cl. (vii)

anchor.surface_text: The larger power, if any, must be held to be cut down by necessary implication.

holdings.text: local authorities like the Board do not act as legislatures when they impose a tax but as the agent of the State Legislatures. Their powers and the extent of these powers must be found in the statute which erects them and endows them with such powers.

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been ruled on many an occasion in this Court that local authorities like the Board do not act as legislatures when they impose a tax but as the agent of the State Legislatures. Their powers and the extent of these powers must be found in the statute which erects them and endows them with such powers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying repeated precedents of this Court on delegated taxing powers of local bodies.

holdings.text: the Board could levy toll only on vehicles entering the municipality and not on vehicles leaving the municipality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express textual limitation in cl.(vii) to vehicles 'entering the municipality'.

holdings.text: Such an extension of power through cl. xiv cannot be supported.

anchor.surface_text: To permit tolls to be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality would render ineffective that part of cl. vii which lays emphasis on vehicles entering the municipality. Such an extension of power through cl. xiv cannot be supported.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Residuary cl.(xiv) cannot override specific limit in cl.(vii) as it would render it ineffective; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: tolls as such can be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality as well as on vehicles entering the municipality--a point which we do not decide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide given statutory limits on municipal power.

holdings.text: the power to collect tolls was limited in 1941 by cl. vii of S. 128(1) and that power continues to be so limited.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, sufficient to say that in the Hardwar Municipality the power to collect tolls was limited in 1941 by cl. vii of S. 128 (1) and that power continues to be so limited. In this view of the matter the distinction made by the Divi-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.(vii) exhausts delegated power; cannot extend by general toll concepts or residuary cl.(xiv).

holdings.text: the distinction made by the Divisional Bench between vehicles which need not pay toll on leaving the municipal limits because they have paid toll on entry and vehicles which have not paid any toll till leaving, may not be quite correct.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the distinction made by the Divisional Bench between vehicles which need not pay toll on leaving the municipal limits because they have paid toll on entry and vehicles which have not paid any toll till leaving, may not be quite correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory power for toll on exit vehicles at all, irrespective of entry payment.

Section 128(1)(vii) explicitly limits toll to vehicles entering the municipality, directly supporting the holding that toll can only be levied on entering vehicles, not leaving.
The concept defining the limit of Section 128(1)(vii) to entering vehicles directly addresses the issue of levying toll on leaving vehicles.
